content: frankie s knitted stuff ten stitch cushion this is another use for the original ten stitch blanket pattern instead of making a big blanket you can use a smaller square to cover a cushion pad giving you a different diagonal pattern on each side of the finished cushion you can use any yarn and needles for your cushion variegated yarns with a long colour run highlight the technique well but i ve also seen some lovely projects using lots of leftover scraps of yarn my cushion i knitted my cushion cover with 140g of sirdar hayfield spirit dk 345 m / 100g the shade i chose is called autumn but there are lots more to choose from i used 3 25 mm / us size 3 needles 1 measurements you will be working a continuous strip of ten stitches joining it as you go obviously the width of that strip and therefore the size of your finished square will be affected by the weight of the yarn you use the size of needles and how tightly or loosely you knit i ll give you the measurements for my cushion cover but basically you need to work until your square is big enough to cover your chosen cushion pad it will be easier to end up with a square the right size if your ten stitch strip isn t too wide thicker yarns will give you a wider strip so bear that in mind when choosing yarn for this project the width of my ten stitch strip was 4 cm / 1½ which meant that every time i added another strip to all four sides of my growing square i made it 8 cm or 3 bigger in theory your finished square needs to have an area that is double the size of your cushion pad i m going to use imperial measurements here as it gives you slightly less scary numbers so … my cushion pad was 14 ² which would have an area of 196 ² that should mean that my finished knitted square would need an area of 392 ² 14 x 14 = 196 x 2 = 392 the square root of 392 are you enjoying this is roughly 19 8 which would suggest that the sides of my knitted square should measure nearly 20 but as we know knitting stretches and a cushion pad isn t flat so in practice the knitted square should be a bit smaller than this calculation would suggest this is a long-winded way of me telling you that my knitted square measured 19 not 20 you will however be glad to know that there is a much simpler way of getting your knitted square to fit although it may involve buying several different size cushion pads put the cushion pad diagonally on your knitting and its points should reach the middle of the knitted square i know why didn t i just say that in the first place 2 getting started
